entry.title: Meetup.com analysis with interactive Data Visualization using D3.js, DC.js andÂ Python
entry.summary:
Data visualization,according to data visualization expert Stephen Few, is:”…a collection of methods that use visual representations to explore, make sense of, and communicate quantitative data”.

Data visualization is an interdisciplinary field, which requires several skills like: coding, web development, design, and database.

The source code for this tutorial can be found in this github repository.
entry.content:
Data visualization,according to data visualization expert Stephen Few, is:”…a collection of methods that use visual representations to explore, make sense of, and communicate quantitative data”.

Data visualization is an interdisciplinary field, which requires several skills like: coding, web development, design, and database.

The source code for this tutorial can be found in this github repository.

Below is an animated gif of the interactive data visualization dashboard that we will build in this tutorial.

1. The case studyÂ¶

This study is aimed to show tech groups in four european countries: France, Beligium, Luxembourg and Swiss. Quick Brainstorm (of desirable hypothesis or questions):

Which cities have a highest number of group or members ?
What about groups creattion by year?
Wich are the biggest groups?
What is their geographic distribution?

We used Meetup.com API in order to get data. Meetup.com is a website used by technologists, coders and entrepreneurs to organise events.

2. My Dataviz ToolchainÂ¶

For our data visualization, we will use these tools:

  • Jupyter Notebook and Python Pandas for getting, cleaning and structuring data

  • Flask for serving static files (html, css and Javascript file) and data to the browser

  • D3.js,DC.js and Leaflet.js for building the charts and map

2. Data PreparationÂ¶

We start by downloading the dataset from meetup.com API (https://www.meetup.com/meetup_api/). You need a key to download the data.

We import python librairies

InÂ [16]:
import urllib.request
import requests
import json
import six
from time import sleep
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
from geopy.geocoders import Nominatim
geolocator = Nominatim()

We generate a list of signed URLs for all given cities

Now, we should solicit signed URL for each search (in our case, city) and output of these signed URLs will provide the detail information about matched groups:

InÂ [17]:
# Create a list of all cities
places = [ "paris", "lyon", "bordeaux", "chartres", "la loupe", "orlÃ©ans", "rennes", "montpellier","strasbourg", "toulouse", "nice", "fontainebleau", "geneve", "brussels", "luxembourg"]
InÂ [18]:
urls = [] #url lists
data_format = "json" #you can add another format like XML
category_id="34" #Id of tech groups
key = "" # initialise with your sign, check sample signed key

We are going to:

  • Create an object to access longitude and latitude of city
  • Access city from given list and generate latitude and longitude using âgeolocatorâ object
  • Generate url string with required attributes like data format(json), radius (number miles from center of the city 50),latitude and longitude
  • Iterate this step for each city and append all URLs in a list
  • Read data from URL and access relevant features in a DataFrame
InÂ [19]:
for place in places: 
        location = geolocator.geocode(place)
        urls.append("https://api.meetup.com/2/groups?offset=0&category;_id=34&format;=" + data_format + "&lon;=" + str(location.longitude) + "&photo-host;=public&page;=20&fields;=⪫=" + str(location.latitude) + "ℴ=id&desc;=false&key;="+key)

Now, we have list of URLs for all cities. Next, we will use urllib.request library to read data into JSON format. Then, weâll read the data to a list before converting it to a DataFrame.

InÂ [20]:
id,name,members,city,country,lat,lon = [],[ ],[ ], [], [], [],[]
InÂ [21]:
for url in urls:
    response = requests.get(url)
    data = json.loads(response.text)
InÂ [22]:
data.keys()
Out[22]:
dict_keys(['results', 'meta'])
InÂ [23]:
data=data["results"]
InÂ [24]:
for i in data:
    id.append(i['id'])
    name.append(i['name'])
    members.append(i['members'])
    city.append(i['city'])
    country.append(i['country'])
    lat.append(i['lat'])
    lon.append(i['lon'])
InÂ [25]:
df = pd.DataFrame([id,name,members, city, country, lat, lon]).T
InÂ [26]:
df.columns=['id','name','members','city','country','lat','lon']#df = df.sort_values(by=['c1','c2'], ascending=[False,True])
InÂ [27]:
df
Out[27]:
id name members city country lat lon
0 192084 Mac User Luxembourg Group 149 Luxembourg LU 49.62 6.12
1 5431352 Data Science Luxembourg 1281 Luxembourg LU 49.62 6.12
2 6823432 Luxembourg Drupal Users and Developers community 45 Luxembourg LU 49.62 6.12
3 8070142 Luxembourg and Greater Region PHP Meetup Group 282 Luxembourg LU 49.62 6.12
4 14829342 Wearable Wednesday Luxembourg 193 Luxembourg LU 49.62 6.12
5 15559472 Geek Girls Carrots Luxembourg 498 Luxembourg LU 49.62 6.12
6 16263302 CoderDojoLu 209 Luxembourg LU 49.62 6.12
7 17357172 Luxembourg Scrum Master Meetup 65 Luxembourg LU 49.62 6.12
8 17761752 Meteor Luxembourg 67 Luxembourg LU 49.62 6.12
9 18338469 JavaScript Luxembourg 686 Luxembourg LU 49.62 6.12
10 18443417 Betacube Community 117 Wormeldange LU 49.6 6.4
11 18462669 AWS User Group Luxembourg 268 Luxembourg LU 49.62 6.12
12 18580486 luxembourg_on_rails.rb 68 Luxembourg LU 49.62 6.12
13 18610243 Luxembourg Data Analytics Meetup 123 Luxembourg LU 49.62 6.12
14 18626883 Luxembourg Bitcoin Meetup 237 Luxembourg LU 49.62 6.12
15 18739600 Docker Luxembourg 269 Luxembourg LU 49.62 6.12
16 19347222 Luxembourg Co-founders Meetup 230 Luxembourg LU 49.62 6.12
17 19491360 Python Trier Meetup 161 Trier DE 49.75 6.63
18 19631843 Antenne AFUP Luxembourg : PHP 113 Luxembourg LU 49.62 6.12
19 19646311 DevOps Luxembourg 176 Luxembourg LU 49.62 6.12

We create a json file wich contains informations about tech groups in France, Luxembourg, Belgium and Swiss.

InÂ [28]:
df.to_json('techgroup.json')

Next, we create another file called app.py inside the project folder. We copy the code below inside the app.py file. This is server side code.

InÂ [Â ]:
    import pandas as pd from shapely.geometry import Point, shape

    from flask import Flask from flask import render_template import json

    data_path = './input/'

    app = Flask(name)

    @app.route("/") def index(): return render_template("index.html")

    @app.route("/data") def get_data():

    df_clean = pd.read_json(data_path + 'techgroups.json')

    return df_clean.to_json(orient='records')


    if name == "main": app.run(host='0.0.0.0',port=5000,debug=True)

From a Terminal window, go to the project folder, and start the server by running the following command.

InÂ [Â ]:
    python app.py

If you start the server by running python app.py and go to http://localhost:5000/, you will see all the projects data printed in the browser.

3. Front-end Side PreparationÂ¶

The server side code is ready, let’s start building the front-end code.

We will use a dashboard template from keen.io.

For building the charts, we’ll use 4 Javascript libraries Crossfilter.js, D3.js and DC.js.

  • Crossfilter.js is a Javascript library for grouping, filtering, and aggregating large datasets.
  • D3.js is a Javascript library for controlling the data and building charts.
  • DC.js is a Javascript charting library that leverages both crossfilter.js and d3.js, and makes the creation of highly interactive data visualization simple.
  • Leaflet.js is JavaScript library for interactive maps. Leaflet has many plugins that can be used to extend its functionalities. We will use the heatmap plugin to show the distribution of tech groups in the map.
  • queue.js Queue is “a plugin that loads external files into the script and ensures each file is completely loaded before allowing the script to continue running.”(Sam Matthews, http://giscollective.org/d3-queue-js/)
  • Underscore.js a library that contains useful functional programming helpers

4. Building the Charts and MapÂ¶

The source code for the charts and map goes into graphs.js.

We start by using a queue() function from the queue.js library for reading the data from the server and executing the function makegraphs(). The queue() function makes sure that we have all the data transferred to the browser before drawing the graphs.

The makeGraphs() function contains the code for cleaning the data, building the crossfilter dimensions for filtering the data, the dc.js charts and the map. It takes 2 arguments, the first one is error which can be used for handling any error from the the .defer function, and as second argument recordsJson which contain the data that we read from the server.

InÂ [Â ]:
queue()
        .defer(d3.json, "/data") 
        .await(makeGraphs);


    function makeGraphs(error, recordsJson) { . . . };

Inside the makeGraphs function, we start by changing the date type from string to datetime objects. We last transform the longitute and latitude types into numeric.

InÂ [Â ]:
 var records = recordsJson; var dateFormat = d3.time.format("%Y").parse;

    _.each(records, function(d) { d["year"] = dateFormat(String(d["year"])); d["Longitude"] = +d["Longitude"];
    d["Latitude"] = +d["Latitude"]; });

Next, we create a crossfilter instance.

InÂ [Â ]:
var ndx = crossfilter(records);
InÂ [Â ]:
Next, we define our 5 data dimensions.
InÂ [Â ]:
    var cityDim = ndx.dimension(function(d) { return d["city"]; });
    var yearDim=ndx.dimension(function (d) { return d["year"];});
    var membersDim = ndx.dimension(function(d) { return d["members"]; });
    var nameGrpDim = ndx.dimension(function(d) { return d["name"]; });
    var locationdDim = ndx.dimension(function(d) { return d["location"]; });
    var allDim = ndx.dimension(function(d) {return d;});
InÂ [Â ]:
Next, we define 4 data groups.
InÂ [Â ]:
    var cityGroup=cityDim.group().reduceCount(function(d) {return d.name;});
    var nameGroup = nameGrpDim.group().reduceSum(function(d) {return d.members/2});
    var citybymembersGroup=cityDim.group().reduceSum(function(d) {return d.members;});
    var meetups = yearDim.group().reduceCount(function(d) {return d.name;});
    var all = ndx.groupAll();

Next, we define four dc charts. The first one is a line chart that will show the number of new tech groups created by year. The second chart is about the ranking of cities by number of groups. The third chart will show the top 30 tech group by members The fourth graph will show the top 30 cities by members

InÂ [Â ]:
    var createdlineChart=dc.lineChart("#chart-line-createdperyear");
    var cityChart = dc.rowChart("#city-row-chart");
    var nameChart = dc.rowChart("#name-row-chart");
    var citybymembersChart=dc.rowChart("#citybymembers-row-chart");

For each chart, we pass the necessary parameters.

InÂ [Â ]:
cityChart 
       .height(450) 
       .width(380) 
       .dimension(cityDim) 
       .group(cityGroup) 
       .rowsCap(20) 
       .ordering(function(d) { return -d.value })

    createdlineChart
        .height(450)
        .width(680)
        .transitionDuration(200)
        .renderLabel(true)
        .dimension(yearDim)
        .group(meetups)
        .margins({top: 10, right: 10, bottom: 20, left: 40})
        .elasticY(true)
        .x(d3.time.scale().domain(d3.extent(records, function(d) { return d.year; })))
        .xAxis()

    nameChart
       .height(450)
       .width(480)
       .dimension(nameGrpDim)
       .group(nameGroup)
       .rowsCap(10)
       .ordering(function(d) { return -d.value })

    citybymembersChart
       .height(950)
       .width(680)
       .dimension(cityDim)
       .group(citybymembersGroup)
       .rowsCap(30)
       .ordering(function(d) { return -d.value })
       ;

Next, we initialize a leaflet map.

InÂ [Â ]:
    var map = L.map('map');

We define a function that will draw the map and adds a layer of heatmap representing the geographical distribution of the Meetup.com tech groups.

InÂ [Â ]:
var drawMap = function(){

    map.setView([47, 2], 5);
    mapLink = 'OpenStreetMap';
    L.tileLayer(
        'http://{s}.tile.openstreetmap.org/{z}/{x}/{y}.png', {
            attribution: 'Â© ' + mapLink + ' Contributors',
            maxZoom: 15,
        }).addTo(map);

    //HeatMap
    var geoData = [];
    _.each(allDim.top(Infinity), function (d) {
        geoData.push([d["Latitude"], d["Longitude"], 1]);
      });
    var heat = L.heatLayer(geoData,{
        radius: 10,
        blur: 20, 
        maxZoom: 1,
    }).addTo(map);

};

We call drawMap() function to display the map.

InÂ [Â ]:
drawMap();

Next we define the rules for updating the map. The code below makes sure that anytime we filter any DC.js charts, we redraw the map with the new filtered data.

InÂ [Â ]:
dcCharts = [cityChart,createdlineChart,nameChart,citybymembersChart];

 _.each(dcCharts, function (dcChart) { dcChart.on("filtered", function (chart, filter) {
    map.eachLayer(function (layer) { map.removeLayer(layer) }); drawMap(); }); });

And finally, we call the renderAll() function for rendering all the charts.

InÂ [Â ]:
dc.renderAll();

All the charts we defined in the chart.js file are dislayed in the index.html file.

ConclusionÂ¶

In this tutorial, I showed a process for building an interactive data visualization.

All source code from this post can be found in this github repository.
